page.title: 03FARMING ON DARTMOOR.
page.content: The open moorland of Dartmoor is used by farmers to graze stock throughout the year. Much of the land is of very poor quality , no attempt having yet been made to improve it despite E.E.C. grants being available. Farmers around the moor have Commoners' rights attached to their land holding which allow them to put stock on the moor. Both sheep, often black face Cheviot crosses and beef cattle, mostly belted Galaway, roam free over wide areas. 'Drifts' bring all the stock off the moor in the annual round up. This allows the lambs and young ponies to be marked or sent to market. At times the farmer suppliments the poor grass with hay, the arrival of the tractor and food giving rise to a 'Wild West' scene the cattle herding in pursuit. The moorland grazing allows farmers to use richer low land to grow fodder.
